awd_titl_txt: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute (EAPSI) for FY 2013 in Australia
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds Amy Truitt of Portland State University to conduct a research project in Biology during the summer of 2013 at Griffith University in Brisbane, Australia.  The project title is "The Role of Symbiotic Bacteria in Providing Viral Resistance in Butterflies; the Potential Implications on Conservation in the Face of Climate Change." The host scientist is Dr. Jeremy Brownlie. 

This project investigates tripartite interactions among bacteria, virus, and Lepidopteran hosts to determine how this interplay will affect management decisions, especially in light of climate change, of imperiled pollinators. The project co-infects caterpillars with either nuclear polyhedris virus (NPV) or flock house virus (FHV) and a series of Wolbachia strains to garner a better understanding the role of Wolbachia in the ecology of its host. This project uniquely evaluates the fitness benefits provided by different strains of Wolbachia to its Lepidopteran host. It also adds to the potential uses of Wolbachia as a bio-control agent or as an influence on bio-control agents, such as the viral-based bio pesticides, employed to control lepidopteran pest species.

Broader impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce. Upon completion of this project the Fellow will continue to work with the Oregon Zoo and U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service to integrate the findings about Wolbachia with the management plan of the imperiled Oregon silverspot butterfly. The findings from this research will be used to develop inquiry-based science projects for K-12 and informal education as well as university classes and will be disseminated to citizens, managers, and scientists. To disseminate the results of these studies, Dr. Browlie and the Fellow will submit teh results of their research to a highly ranked journal and will present the findings at both national and international conferences. Interesting advances will be communicated to the wider community via Griffith University and Portland State University marketing and communications offices, and via mechanisms such as publication in the publicly available magazine Australasian Science. The Fellow will also continue presentations at community center seminars in the United States.

Conservation strategies for imperiled butterfly species include assisted migration and population reintroductions. These strategies, however, increase exposure to pathogenic viruses. Global climate change also is predicted to create new mixes of pollinator communities, which will likely spread bacteria and viruses within and among species. Wolbachia, an endosymbiotic bacterium that occurs in approximately 40% of insects (Zug & Hammerstein 2012) has been shown to confer viral resistance to Dipteran (fly) hosts (Hedges et al. 2008; Brownlie & Johnson 2009). The proposed study aimed to determine if Wolbachia provides its Lepidopteran (butterflies and moths) hosts with resistance to deadly viruses. I used fruit flies as a model system due to the timing of the fellwoship. I infected fruit fly larvae with a virus and a series of Wolbachia strains to garner a better understanding the role of Wolbachia in the ecology of its hosts. My initial results indicate that Wolbachia does indeed provide its host with viral resistance at the larval stage. I will be applying the training and techniques that I learned through this project to Lepidoptera catepillars at my university.

In addition to addressing questions about its potential to confer viral resistance, the data from this project will be included in a model that evaluates how infection by multiple strains of Wolbachia will affect butterfly populations over different time scales. The model will examine the benefits of any viral resistance as well as Wolbachia’s effects on reproductive output. Wolbachia can affect reproductive output of hosts in various ways (Werren et al. 2008). For example, the most commonly observed reproductive manipulation of Wolbachia causes cytoplasmic incompatibility (CI) in its hosts (Werren 1997; Werren et al. 2008). CI substantially reduces the fitness (ability to survive and reproduce) of females uninfected with the strain(s) of their mates. Hence, Wolbachia confers a relative advantage to the genes of infected females but could cause population collapse, especially in small populations (Truitt et al. in prep). The net reproductive and viral- resistance effects of Wolbachia need to be modeled to understand likely impacts to small populations across different scenarios and I will be doing this as part of my dissertation.

My results from this project and the continuation of this work will help to inform and develop imperiled butterfly conservation strategies. Current conservation strategies that employ assisted migrations or species reintroductions do not operate under a full understanding of the insect-microbe associations; it is my objective to integrate microbial ecology into international conservation and pollinator management programs. These concepts have potential to shift the fundamental design of insect conservation management, particularly in the face of climate change.
